> The diff coverage is `100%`.

[![Impacted file tree graph](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806/graphs/tree.svg?width=650&token=eZ4WkYLtcO&height=150&src=pr)](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806?src=pr&el=tree)

|---|---|---|

| [pandas/core/arrays/datetimes.py](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806/diff?src=pr&el=tree#diff-cGFuZGFzL2NvcmUvYXJyYXlzL2RhdGV0aW1lcy5weQ==) | `97.79% <100%> (+0.01%)` | :arrow_up: |
| [pandas/core/indexes/base.py](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806/diff?src=pr&el=tree#diff-cGFuZGFzL2NvcmUvaW5kZXhlcy9iYXNlLnB5) | `96.32% <100%> (ø)` | :arrow_up: |

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [0f84b40...a9a9588](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Fixed the merge conflict.

I'm inclined to keep the change of `DatetimeIndex([1, 2], dtype='datetime64[us])` raising, as the user is unambiguously asking for something wrong (in comparison with `'datetime64'`, which is ambiguous, so we deprecate it).

All green. Anyone else (@jorisvandenbossche @jbrockmendel) have an opinion on whether this should warn or raise?

```python
In [3]: pd.DatetimeIndex(['2000'], dtype='datetime64[us]')
Out[3]: DatetimeIndex(['2000-01-01'], dtype='datetime64[ns]', freq=None)
```

On 0.23 that silently ignored the precision.

On master (and this PR) we raise.
No strong opinion on raise vs warn for datetime64[us]

> On 0.23 that silently ignored the precision.

Pedantic note: it doesn't really "ignores the precision" in this example case, as it is doing "datetime string parsing", even if you pass `dtype=datetime64[ns]` it doesn't use the ns precision to interpret the string value '2000'. 
But we do ignore it for integer input:

```
In [10]: pd.DatetimeIndex([2000], dtype='datetime64[s]')
Out[10]: DatetimeIndex(['1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002'], dtype='datetime64[ns]', freq=None)
```

so in the end my note doesn't matter :), because here it is indeed being ignored, and fine to raise an error here.

> fine to raise an error here.

Actually, this already seems to be failing on master:

```
In [86]: pd.DatetimeIndex([2000], dtype='datetime64[s]')                                                                                                                        
...
ValueError: Unexpected value for 'dtype': 'datetime64[s]'. Must be 'datetime64[ns]' or DatetimeTZDtype'.
```

So we already changed this (by accident?) compared to 0.23.4.

@jorisvandenbossche can you explain your conclusion in 
https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806#issuecomment-455458403 and 
https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24806#issuecomment-455458041 a bit further? I don't see where the precision is being used for parsing (strings or ints), though maybe that's what you're saying?

On 0.23.4

```python
In [3]: pd.DatetimeIndex([2000], dtype='datetime64[s]')
Out[3]: DatetimeIndex(['1970-01-01 00:00:00.000002'], dtype='datetime64[ns]', freq=None)
```

i.e. the same a `datetime64[ns]`. You could imagine it being used as the "unit" parameter for Timestamp for interpreting the integers, but that's not what we did on 0.23.4.

---

So to summarize *my* understanding, which may be wrong

1. In 0.23.4 DatetimeIndex completely ignored the precision.
2. Master currently raises for anything that is non-ns, including no precision.
3. I think we should warn for `dtype='datetime64'` (no precision) since it's ambiguous.
4. I think we should 4raise for `dtype='datetime64[s]'` (non-ns precision) since it's wrong.

those all apply to TimedeltaIndex and Index as well.

Specifically

> Pedantic note: it doesn't really "ignores the precision" in this example case, as it is doing "datetime string parsing", even if you pass dtype=datetime64[ns] it doesn't use the ns precision to interpret the string value '2000'.


Two things there confused me

1. I'm not sure how the precision would affect parsing of strings at all. To me, those don't have an *input* precision (but end up with a precision when they're a Timestamp / array)
2. The `dtype` parameter to Index/DatetimeIndex/TimedeltaIndex means the *desired output dtype*. Not anything to do with parsing, or the input dtype of `data`.

Yes, the confusing part (or at least why my comment was also confusing / wrong), is the difference of input vs output dtype. About my comment that the precision is ignored for string parsing, that was indeed assuming that the `dtype` argument would give an indication about the provided input data. But of course, that is not the case. 

Basically, the whole `dtype` argument is just completely useless (apart from consistency with the other constructors, the reason we have it I assume), as there is only one possible dtype (note: this is only true for tz naive of course, but for that there is also the `tz` keyword).
